case_name: Jai Jai Ram Manohar Lal v. National Building Material Supply, Gurgaon

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 697 of 1966 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 697 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated November 9, 1964 of Allahabad High Court in First Appeal No. 257 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 9, 1964 of the Allahabad High Court in First Appeal No. 257 of 1953. C. Manchanda, S. k. Mehta and K. L. Mehta, for the appellant.

facts.text: On March 11, 1950, Manohar Lal s/o Jai Jai Ram commenced an action in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Nainital, for Rs. 10,139/12/- being the value of timber supplied to the defendant National Building Material Supply, Gurgaon.

anchor.surface_text: On March 11, 1950, Manohar Lal s o Jai Jai Ram companymenced an action in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Nanital, for a decree for Rs. 10,139/12/- being the value of timber supplied to the defendant-the National Building Mate- rial Supply, Gurgaon.

facts.text: The action was instituted in the name of Jai Jai Ram Manohar Lal.

anchor.surface_text: The action was instituted in the name of Jai Jai Ram Manohar Lal which was the name in which the business was carried on. The plaintiff Manohar Lal subscribed his signature at the foot of the plaint as Jai Jai Ram Manohar Lal, by the pen of Manohar Lal, and the plaint was also similarly verified.

facts.text: Defendant contended that the plaintiff was an unregistered firm and incompetent to sue.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant by its written statement companytended that the plaintiff was an unregistered firm and on that account incompetent to sue.

facts.text: On July 18, 1952, the plaintiff applied for leave to amend the plaint.

anchor.surface_text: On July 18, 1952, the plaintiff applied for leave to amend the plaint. Manohar Lal stated that the business name of the plaintiff is Jai Jai Ram Manohar Lal and therein Manohar Lal the owner and proprietor is clearly shown and -named.

facts.text: Manohar Lal stated that Jai Jai Ram Manohar Lal is a joint Hindu family business and he is the proprietor.

anchor.surface_text: Manohar Lal stated that the business name of the plaintiff is Jai Jai Ram Manohar Lal and therein Manohar Lal the owner and proprietor is clearly shown and -named. It is a joint Hindu family business and the defendant and all knew it that Manohar, Lai whose name is there along with the fathers name is the proprietor of it.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge granted leave to amend the plaint.

anchor.surface_text: Apparently numberreply was filed to this application by the defendant. The Subordinate Judge granted leave to amend the plaint. He observed that there was numberdoubt that the real plaintiff was Manohar Lal himself, that it was Manohar Lal who intended to file and did in fact Me the action,

facts.text: Defendant filed supplementary written statement contending Manohar Lal was not the sole owner and his brothers were also owners.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant then filed a supplementary written statement raising two additional companytentions- 1  that Manohar Lal was number the sole owner of the business and that his other brothers were also the owners of the business and  2  that in any event the amendment became effective from July 18, 1952,

facts.text: Defendant contended that amendment effective from July 18, 1952, and suit barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: and  2  that in any event the amendment became effective from July 18, 1952, and on that account the suit was barred by the law of limitation. The Trial Judge decreed the claim for Rs. 6,568/6/3.

facts.text: Trial Judge decreed the claim for Rs. 6,568/6/3.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Judge decreed the claim for Rs. 6,568/6/3. Against that decree an appeal was preferred to the High Court of Allahabad.

facts.text: Appeal preferred to Allahabad High Court against trial decree.

anchor.surface_text: Against that decree an appeal was preferred to the High Court of Allahabad. The High Court being of the view that the action was instituted in the name of a number-existing person

facts.text: Allahabad High Court held suit was a nullity and dismissed it on ground of limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court after making an extensive quotation from the judgment of this Court in purushottam Umedbhai and Company v. Messrs. Manilal and Sons 1  observed that the action companyld number be instituted by the plaintiff in the business name it should have been instituted in the name of the Karta of the Hindu undivided family in his representative capacity or else all the members of the joint family must join as plaintiffs. The Court then observed The suit instituted by the joint Hindu family business in the name of an assumed business title was a suit by a person, who did number exist and was, therefore, a nullity.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff has appealed to this Court with special leave.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that the amendment was rightly allowed by trial court and High Court erred.

anchor.surface_text: The order passed by the High Court cannot be sustained. Rules of procedure are intended to, be a handmaid to the administration of justice. ... In our view, the order passed by the Trial Court in granting the amendment was clearly right, and the High Court was in error in dismissing the suit on a technicality wholly unrelated to the merits of the dispute.

facts.text: Plaintiff carried on business as commission agent in the name of Jai Jai Ram Manohar Lal.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the plaintiff was carrying on business as companymission agent in the name of Jai Jai Ram Manohar Lal. The plaintiff was companypetent to sue in his own name as Manager of the Hindu undivided family to which the business belonged he says he sued on behalf of the family in the business name.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and set aside High Court decree.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed and the decree passed by the High Court is set aside. It appears that the High Court has number dealt with the appeal on the merits.

facts.text: High Court did not deal with the appeal on merits.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the High Court has number dealt with the appeal on the merits.

facts.text: Defendant to pay costs in Supreme Court and High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Since all this delay has taken place and companyts have been thrown away, because the defendant raised and persisted in a plea which had numbermerit even after the amendment was allowed by the Trial Court, he must pay the companyts in this Court and the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Hence there could be no amendment of the description of such a plaintiff who did not exist in the eye of law. The court below was in obvious error in thinking otherwise and allowing the name of Manohar Lal to be added as proprietor of the original plaintiff Jai Jai Ram Manohar Lal, which was neither a legal entity nor an existing person who could have validly instituted the suit. The High Court was also of the opinion that the substitution of the name of Manohar Lal as a plaintiff during the pendency of the action took effect from July 18, 1952, and the action must be deemed to be instituted on that date the amendment could not take effect retrospectively and on the date of the amendment the action was barred by the law of limitation.

arguments.claim: Rules of procedure are handmaid to administration of justice; party cannot be refused relief for mistake or negligence

anchor.surface_text: The order passed by the High Court cannot be sustained. Rules of procedure are intended to, be a handmaid to the administration of justice. A party cannot be refused just relief merely because of some mistake, negligence, inadvertence or even infraction of the rules of procedure.

arguments.claim: Court always gives leave to amend unless mala fide or caused irremediable injury to opponent compensable by costs

anchor.surface_text: The Court always gives leave to amend the pleading of a party, unless it is satisfied that the party applying was acting mala fide, or that by his blunder, he had caused injury to his opponent which may not be compensated for by an order of costs. However negligent or careless may have been the first omission, and, however late the proposed amendment, the amendment may be allowed if it can be made without injustice to the other side.

arguments.claim: Question turns on whether suit in name of non-existent person (nullity, no amendment) or misdescription of existing persons (amendable with costs)

anchor.surface_text: In Amulakchand Mewaram and others v. Babulal Kanalal Taliwala , Beaumont, C.J., in delivering the judgment of the Bombay High Court set out the principles applicable to cases like the present and observed the question whether there should be an amendment or not really turns upon whether the name in which the suit is brought in the name of a non-existent person or whether it is merely a misdescription of existing persons. If the former is the case, the suit is a nullity and no amendment can cure it.

arguments.claim: Suit in firm name not within O.30 CPC but case of misdescription of existing persons; amendment ought to be allowed

anchor.surface_text: In Amulakchand Mewarams case a Hindu undivided family sued in its business name. ... In appeal the High Court observed that a suit brought in the name of a firm in a case not within O. 30 C.P. Code being in fact a case of misdescription of existing persons, leave to amend ought to have been given.

arguments.claim: Plaint in firm name outside India is misdescription, not nullity; amendable under s.153 or O.VI r.17 to determine real controversy

anchor.surface_text: This Court considered a somewhat similar case in Purushottam Umedbhais case . ... in these circumstances, a civil court could permit, under the provisions of s. 153 of the Code  or possibly under O. VI, r. 17, ... an amendment of the plaint to enable a proper description of the plaintiffs to appear in it in order to assist the Court in determining the real question or issue between the parties.

arguments.claim: All amendments permitted necessary for determining real controversy unless injustice to other side
Plaintiff carrying on business as commission agent in name Jai Jai Ram Manohar Lal; competent to sue as manager of HUF

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the plaintiff was carrying on business as commission agent in the name of Jai Jai Ram Manohar Lal. The plaintiff was competent to sue in his own name as Manager of the Hindu undivided family to which the business belonged he says he sued on behalf of the family in the business name.

arguments.claim: No rule that application for amendment must expressly aver bona fide mistake; power to amend serves ends of justice, not technical limits

anchor.surface_text: The observations made by the High Court that the application for amendment of the plaint could not be granted, because there was no averment therein that the misdescription was on account of a bona fide mistake, and on that account the suit must fail, cannot be accepted. In our view, there is no rule that unless in an application for amendment of the plaint it is expressly averred that the error, omission or misdescription is due to a bona fide mistake, the Court has no power to grant leave to amend the plaint.

arguments.claim: Name in which action instituted was merely misdescription of original plaintiff; no question of limitation, relates back to original date

anchor.surface_text: The power to grant amendment of the pleadings is intended to serve the ends of justice and is not governed by any such narrow or technical limitations. Since the name in which the action was instituted was merely a misdescription of the original plaintiff, no question of limitation arises the plaint must be deemed on amendment to have been instituted in the name of the real plaintiff, on the date on which it was originally instituted.

arguments.claim: Trial court granting amendment was right; High Court erred in dismissing on technicality unrelated to merits

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the order passed by the Trial Court in granting the amendment was clearly right, and the High Court was in error in dismissing the suit on a technicality wholly unrelated to the merits of the dispute.

arguments.claim: Defendant must pay costs because raised and persisted in plea with no merit even after amendment allowed

anchor.surface_text: Since all this delay has taken place and costs have been thrown away, because the defendant raised and persisted in a plea which had no merit even after the amendment was allowed by the Trial Court, he must pay the costs in this Court and the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished nullity (non-existent person) from misdescription (existing plaintiff/HUF manager) following precedents like Purushottam Umedbhai (firm name outside India misdescription) and Amulakchand (HUF business name misdescription); applied to facts where plaintiff sued in business name as HUF manager.

holdings.text: there is no rule that unless in an application for amendment of the plaint it is expressly averred that the error, omission or misdescription is due to a bona fide mistake, the Court has no power to grant leave to amend the plaint

anchor.surface_text: The observations made by the High Court that the application for amendment of the plaint could not be granted, because there was no averment therein that the misdescription was on account of a bona fide mistake, and on that account

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejected High Court's technical requirement as contrary to purposive interpretation of amendment powers under CPC ss.153/O.VI r.17; amendment serves justice without narrow limitations.

holdings.text: no question of limitation arises the plaint must be deemed on amendment to have been instituted in the name of the real plaintiff, on the date on which it was originally instituted

anchor.surface_text: of the original plaintiff, no question of limitation arises the plaint must be deemed on amendment to have been instituted in the name of the real plaintiff, on the date on which it was originally instituted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since mere misdescription (not new plaintiff), amendment relates back to original institution date (March 11, 1950); rejected High Court's view of fresh institution on amendment date (July 18, 1952).

holdings.text: the order passed by the Trial Court in granting the amendment was clearly right, and the High Court was in error in dismissing the suit on a technicality wholly unrelated to the merits of the dispute

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the order passed by the Trial Court in granting the amendment was clearly right, and the High Court was in error in dismissing the suit on a technicality wholly unrelated to the merits of the dispute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial court correctly recognized real plaintiff (Manohar Lal) and allowed amendment to conform form to substance; High Court wrongly treated as incurable nullity despite no prejudice/injustice.

holdings.text: Rules of procedure are intended to, be a handmaid to the administration of justice. A party cannot be refused just relief merely because of some mistake, negligence, inadvertence or even infraction of the rules of procedure
